articles.headline: Erdogan Faces a Challenge He Can’t Easily Bully: Turkey’s Economy
articles.snippet: Turks are bracing for more financial turmoil. Economists warn that the problem is broader and deeper than a spat with the United States.
articles.abstract: Turks are bracing for more financial turmoil. Economists warn that the problem is broader and deeper than a spat with the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has long made clear that he considered no part of Turkish life beyond his reach, not least the economy.

articles.headline: This Company Keeps Lies About Sandy Hook on the Web
articles.snippet: The father of a victim of the Sandy Hook shooting has tried to erase lies about his son from the internet, but Automattic, which runs WordPress.com, says “untrue content is not banned.”
articles.abstract: The father of a victim of the Sandy Hook shooting has tried to erase lies about his son from the internet, but Automattic, which runs WordPress.com, says “untrue content is not banned.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Leonard Pozner says he spends hours every day trying to erase online conspiracy theories that the death of his 6-year-old son Noah at the Sandy Hook Elementary School was a hoax.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and John Herrman

articles.headline: Elon Musk’s Tweets on Tesla Started a Tizzy. Someone Should Hit the Brakes.
articles.snippet: Executives are permitted to disclose market-moving information on social media. But Mr. Musk has provided regulators ample opportunity to re-examine the policy.
articles.abstract: Executives are permitted to disclose market-moving information on social media. But Mr. Musk has provided regulators ample opportunity to re-examine the policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Why do people say the craziest things on Twitter?

articles.headline: A Year After Charlottesville, Disarray in the White Supremacist Movement
articles.snippet: “It was a dead-enders event from the get-go.” The alt-right’s sparse turnout at a Washington rally on Sunday illustrated a fracturing within the movement.
articles.abstract: “It was a dead-enders event from the get-go.” The alt-right’s sparse turnout at a Washington rally on Sunday illustrated a fracturing within the movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The white supremacists who alarmed the nation a year ago on the streets of Charlottesville, Va., with their tiki torches and hateful chants show signs, at least temporarily, of being pushed back into the shadows after months of legal challenges, counterprotests and internal strife.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset, Serge F. Kovaleski and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Trump Calls Omarosa Manigault Newman ‘That Dog’ in His Latest Insult
articles.snippet: Ms. Manigault Newman responded that Mr. Trump, who has also insulted Don Lemon and LeBron James, “has absolutely no respect for women, for African-Americans.’’
articles.abstract: Ms. Manigault Newman responded that Mr. Trump, who has also insulted Don Lemon and LeBron James, “has absolutely no respect for women, for African-Americans.’’
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump added his former White House aide, Omarosa Manigault Newman, on Tuesday to the growing list of African-Americans he has publicly denigrated on Twitter, calling her “that dog” and a “crazed, crying lowlife” after her allegations against him of mental deterioration and racism.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: Trump’s Trade War Is Rattling China’s Leaders
articles.snippet: While President Xi Jinping remains firmly in charge, friction with the Trump administration and troubles at home have dented his political dominance.
articles.abstract: While President Xi Jinping remains firmly in charge, friction with the Trump administration and troubles at home have dented his political dominance.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s leaders have sought to project confidence in the face of President Trump’s tariffs and trade threats. But as it becomes clear that a protracted trade war with the United States may be unavoidable, there are growing signs of unease inside the Communist political establishment.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Steven Lee Myers
